questions.question: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to the passage of blood in her urine, along with complaints of left flank pain, fatigue and generalised weakness. She has a history of recurrent renal stones. USG confirmed the presence of renal stones in her left renal pelvis. Lab reports show the following values. Based on the values given below, what is the most likely diagnosis? Blood pH - 7.29 Serum sodium - 144 mEq/L Serum potassium - 3.1 mEq/L Serum bicarbonate - 9 mEq/L Urine pH - 5.8 Urine calcium - elevated Urine citrate - low Normal anion gap
questions.explanation: renal stones , it is most likely due to Type 1 Renal tubular acidosis. Type 1 renal tubular acidosis Defect Inability of the alpha intercalated cells (DCT) to secrete H+ into urine § Metabolic acidosis I H+ excretion leads to I K+ reabsorption § Hypokalemia renal tubular acidosis " data-author="" data-hash="8420" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="531" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/P5k1cj5pstPpIuHdSo6C1744277453.png" width="531" /> Serum electrolytes Hypokalemia Urine changes Hypocitraturia, hypercalciuria, pH> 5.5 Causes Amphotericin B Analgesic toxicity Lithium toxicity Autoimmunity (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome) Hyperglobulinemia Association Nephrolithiasis Nephrocalcinosis Osteopenia / osteomalacia / Rickets Management Oral sodium bicarbonate § Neutralizes acidosis Treating hypokalemia (potassium citrate) Type 2 Renal tubular acidosis (Option A) is associated with glycosuria , aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, and hypokalemia. Urine pH depends on the serum bicarbonate level; when serum bicarbonate is low, urine pH is less than 5.5, and vice versa. Hyperparathyroidism (Option B) can cause hypercalcemia , which leads to hypercalciuria and renal stones, but metabolic acidosis is not a feature of hyperparathyroidism. It usually presents with features of hypercalcemia, such as renal stones, osteoporosis, abdominal pain and confusion/irritability (Stones, Bones, Groans and psychiatric overtones) Hypoaldosteronism (Option C) causes hyperkalemia and less NH4+ secretion in the urine, thus causing mild metabolic acidosis. It is typically associated with urine pH< 5.5, and there is no association with renal stones.

questions.question: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a regular annual check-up. Her blood tests reveal a serum bicarbonate level of 12 mEq/L, serum potassium of 3.2 mEq/L, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Urine pH is 5.2, and aminoaciduria and glycosuria are detected despite normal blood glucose levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: syndrome. Proximal RTA occurs due to defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis and low serum bicarbonate. Despite the acidosis, the kidneys can still acidify the urine, resulting in a urine pH below 5.5. Hypokalemia (serum potassium of 3.2 mEq/L) is also a feature of proximal RTA. Type 2 Renal tubular acidosis Defect Defective HCO3- reabsorption in the PCT § Metabolic acidosis Serum electrolytes Hypokalemia Due to I HCO3 I loss § Higher sodium delivery to the distal tubule § Increased potassium excretion § Hypokalemia Urine changes Glycosuria , aminoaciduria , phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome) pH< 5.5 Causes Fanconi syndrome Wilson's disease Multiple myeloma (Paraproteinaemia) Heavy metals (Lead, cadmium, mercury) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors Tenofovir, topiramate Expired tetracycline Galactosemia Cystinosis Cisplatin therapy Association Hypophosphatemic rickets in Fanconi syndrome Treatment Oral sodium bicarbonate Thiazide diuretics Distal Renal tubular acidosis (Option A) is type 1 RTA, which occurs due to the inability of alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) to secrete H+, leading to urine pH >5.5 despite metabolic acidosis. It is characterised by hypokalemia, hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria and is associated with osteomalacia/rickets, nephrolithiasis, and nephrocalcinosis. Generalised Renal tubular acidosis (Option B) is type 4 RTA and is characterised by hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance. Urinary ammonium excretion is depressed; thus, there is mild metabolic acidosis, and the urine pH is typically <5.5. Bartter syndrome (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting Na+/K+/Cl- in the thick ascending loop of Henle . It is characterised by metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hypercalciuria.

He has hypertension and chronic kidney disease and is currently taking metformin, spironolactone, and furosemide. If diagnosed with Type 4 renal tubular acidosis, which finding would be least likely in his investigation report?
questions.explanation: distinguishing it from other forms of RTA (Type 1 and 2) where hypokalemia is common. questions.question: A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family due to 2 days of persistent vomiting, nausea, confusion, and deep, rapid breathing. Her family reports that she has been lethargic and disoriented, with increasing difficulty responding to questions. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Based on the lab findings given below, identify the type of metabolic disorder. Blood pH - 7.28 Sodium - 140 mEq/L Potassium - 5.4 mEq/L Bicarbonate - 10 mEq/L Chloride - 98 mEq/l pCO2 - 22 mm hg pO2 - 95 mmHg RBS - 382 mg/dL
questions.explanation: investigation values given, this patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) due to Diabetic ketoacidosis. Normal blood pH: 7.37-7.42 Anion gap (AG) = [Na I ] - ([Cl I ] + [HCO II ]) Normal AG = 8-12 mEq/L From the given scenario Blood pH= 7.28, which is lower than the normal range: Acidosis Bicarbonate= 10 mEq/L and pCO2= 22 mmHg: Metabolic Anion gap = [Na I ] - ([Cl I ] + [HCO II ]) AG=140 - (98+10) = 32, which is higher than the normal range: High anion Gap Metabolic acidosis High anion gap Non-anion gap M ethanol poisoning U remia: AKI, CKD D iabetic ketoacidosis P aracetamol poisoning I ron and isoniazid L actic acidosis E thylene glycol poisoning S alicylate poisoning H yperchloremia A ddison's disease R enal tubular acidosis D iarrhoea and conditions causing GI loss of HCO3- (ureterosigmoidostomy or external bowel drainage) A cetazolamide S pironolactone and K-sparing diuretics S aline infusion (rapid infusion ) Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome Respiratory acidosis (Option C) occurs when pCO2 is elevated (above 45 mm hg) . In this patient, the pCO2 is low, which rather indicates compensatory hyperventilation for the metabolic acidosis leading to CO2 washout. Metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is characterised by elevated HCO3 and increased blood pH. Moreover, rather than hyperventilating, respiratory compensation occurs by reducing the respiratory rate to retain CO2. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 359 - 361, 364.

questions.question: Clinical question A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, recurrent kidney stones, a history of recurrent UTIs, occasional nausea, vomiting, tingling in her hands and feet, and bone pain. Laboratory results show serum bicarbonate = 15 mEq/L, serum potassium = 1.9 mEq/L, and urine pH = 6. Which of the following is true regarding the anion gap in this condition?

options.A: High in both plasma and urine
options.B: High in plasma, normal in urine
options.C: Normal in plasma, high in urine
options.D: Normal in both plasma and urine

questions.explanation: low serum bicarbonate and potassium, is most likely indicative of renal tubular acidosis (RTA), in which the urine anion gap is elevated while the plasma anion gap stays normal. Anion gap (AG) = [Na I ] - ([Cl I ] + [HCO II ]) Normal AG = 8-12 mEq/L Normal plasma anion gap metabolic acidosis can be seen in, Anion gap RTA Diarrhea Plasma Normal Normal Urine Positive Negative Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 350.

O/E, the physician notes a bruit over the right flank. Renal imaging shows the finding, as given in the image. What is the most common cause of the condition in this patient?
questions.explanation: bruit over the flank and imaging showing an asymmetric shrunk kidney suggests Renal Artery Stenosis (RAS). questions.question: A 68-year-old male presents with resistant high blood pressure despite multiple antihypertensive medications. Imaging studies show an asymmetric shrunken kidney on the left side. Which of the following diagnostic methods is considered the gold standard for confirming the suspected condition?
questions.explanation: standard for confirming RAS , as it allows for direct visualisation of the renal arteries, enabling precise assessment of the severity and location of any stenosis. Investigations for Renal Artery Stenosis: Doppler Ultrasound: Measures blood flow velocities in the renal arteries to evaluate for stenosis. Non-invasive and provides real-time assessment of hemodynamics. Duplex Ultrasonography: Assesses renal artery flow and detects stenosis. Inexpensive, widely available, and suitable for follow-up. Less effective for diagnosing fibromuscular dysplasia Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA): (Option B) Visualises renal arteries & perirenal aorta & non-nephrotoxic Expensive & not suitable for patients with GFR <30 mL/min due to gadolinium toxicity & cannot visualise stented vessels. Computed Tomographic Angiography (CTA): (Option C) Offers detailed images of renal arteries and surrounding structures. Excellent visualisation; stents do not cause artifacts & require contrast Intraarterial Angiography: (Gold standard) Directly visualises renal arteries to assess for stenosis & Allows for simultaneous intervention. Invasive, expensive, and risk of atheroembolism and contrast toxicity. Captopril Renography with Technetium-99m (99mTc MAG3): (Option A) Evaluates renal function and perfusion changes after captopril administration. Enhances the detection of differences in renal perfusion due to induced changes in filtration pressure; a normal study can exclude renovascular hypertension. Less reliable in patients with advanced atherosclerosis or serum creatinine levels >2.0 mg/dL (177 µ mol/L). Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2089

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with severe hypertension (BP 220/140 mmHg), headache, and altered mental status. Fundoscopy shows retinal haemorrhages, and laboratory tests indicate elevated serum creatinine. What histopathological finding is most likely seen in the kidney of this patient?
questions.explanation: declining renal function along with retinal haemorrhages points towards Malignant hypertension. Fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of malignant hypertension , indicating severe damage to the vascular structures. Malignant Hypertension: (Arteriolonephrosclerosis) It is characterized by the rapidly progressive increase in blood pressure (BP) leading to target organ damage, including: Retinal haemorrhages Encephalopathy Declining kidney function - rising creatinine and occasionally hematuria and proteinuria Cause: Activation of the RAAS and severe vasospasm due to catecholamine release. Endothelial injury can also provoke microangiopathic hemolysis. Mortality rates exceed 50% within 6 to 12 months in untreated cases. Histopathology: Fibrinoid necrosis involves the breakdown of vessel walls, accumulation of eosinophilic material (including fibrin), and a surrounding infiltration of cells. Onionskin lesions : These lesions, seen in larger interlobular arteries, exhibit hyperplastic proliferation of vascular wall cells, collagen deposition, and separation of vessel layers. These pathological changes can lead to obliteration of glomeruli and tubular structures, resulting in progressive kidney failure, often requiring dialysis for survival. Biochemical Findings: Evidence of hemolysis (anaemia, schistocytes, and reticulocytosis) Management: The primary treatment is aggressive Antihypertensive therapy. Current survival rates over five years exceed 50% with proper management. Hyaline arteriolosclerosis (Option B) is commonly associated with chronic hypertension; it is not the primary finding in malignant hypertension. Diffuse glomerulosclerosis (Option C) typically occurs in chronic kidney diseases and is characterised by scarring in the glomeruli. While it can be seen in patients with longstanding hypertension, it is not specific to the acute changes associated with malignant hypertension. Tubulointerstitial fibrosis (Option D) refers to scarring of the kidney interstitium and tubules, often seen in chronic kidney diseases. It does not represent the acute vascular changes seen in malignant hypertension, where fibrinoid necrosis is the hallmark finding.
